qas.question: What norms are generally antagonistic to hunting?
What sect lays special emphasis on conservation of particular species?

Who may permit a person to hunt animals in India despite it being banned?
Whose property does the body of any wild animal killed or wounded become?

What bans the killing of all wild animals?

context: <a0_0>Regional social<a0_0/> norms are generally antagonistic to hunting, while a few sects, such as the <a1_0><a5_0><b10_0>Bishnoi<b10_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/>, lay special emphasis on the conservation of particular species, such as the antelope. <a6_0>India's <a2_0><b12_0>Wildlife Protection Act<b12_0/><a6_0/> of <a7_0><b14_0>1972<b14_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> bans the killing of <b11_0>all wild animals<b11_0/>. However, <a3_0>the <a8_0>Chief Wildlife Warden<a8_0/><a3_0/> may, if satisfied that any wild animal from a specified list has become dangerous to human life, or is so disabled or diseased as to be beyond recovery, permit any person to hunt such an animal. In this case, the body of <b13_0>any wild animal<b13_0/> killed or wounded <a9_0>becomes <a4_0>government<a4_0/> property<a9_0/>.
